image.altText: The 250 metre-tall tower in the middle of Noor Energy solar plant.

props.synopsis: This solar thermal plant in the United Arab Emirates could harness enough of the Sun's rays to power a city the size of Brisbane for a year but being able to run one in Australia could prove difficult.

title.children: In the UAE desert, a mysterious beacon looms large. Experts say it could help Australia go green

image.altText: A woman with black hair wears a grey blazer and looks to the left

props.synopsis: Tasmania's primary industries minister says "nothing is off the table" as the government acts to ensure what she has called distressing images of animal cruelty in a leaked animal rights video does not happen again.

title.children: 'Nothing off the table': Minister warns abattoir industry after 'distressing' slaughter video released

image.altText: A JB Hi-FI sign outside a shop with two people walking past.

props.synopsis: Is an extended warranty worth your money? It's a question being raised in a new class action against retail giant JB Hi-Fi.

title.children: JB Hi-Fi accused of profiting off extended warranties, offering people 'what they already get for free'

image.altText: large ship labeled "china coast guard" blasts a smaller ship with strong stream of water

props.synopsis: A Philippine boat and a Chinese Coast Guard ship collided near a hotly contested reef on Sunday, with both countries trading blame for the latest such confrontation in the disputed South China Sea.Â

title.children: Philippine and Chinese vessels collide in disputed South China Sea

image.altText: a pile of gold bullion and coins

props.synopsis: It took seven years of expensive, drawn-out legal battles, but one of the oldest and biggest private precious metals companies in Australia closed a dark chapter in the gold refining industry with a recent win against the ATO, writes Adele Ferguson.

title.children: Police raids, criminal gangs and $1 billion: Inside the gold scam that made a fortune off a GST loophole

image.altText: The University of New South Wales (UNSW) library is seen against a bright, cloudy sky

props.synopsis: UNSW has been conducting a "preliminary" investigation into research misconduct for more than two years. Now the university itself will be investigated.

title.children: Experts call for research misconduct watchdog as UNSW faces investigation

image.altText: Milei standing at a podium speaking into microphones holding up a fist

props.synopsis: Argentinian President Javier Milei takes office warning of dark times as he attempts to guide the nation out of its worst economic crisis in decades, with inflation heading towards 200 per cent.Â

title.children: 'Debt bombs' and 'no money': Argentina President Javier Milei delivers bleak inauguration speech

image.altText: A crowd pulses through the city

props.synopsis: Minimum English language requirements for international students will be increased, and more restrictions will be applied to stop onshore "visa hopping" as the federal government sets its new migration strategy.

title.children: New migration strategy to clamp down on migrants living in Australia in a 'permanently temporary' state

image.altText: Treasurer Jim Chalmers holds a copy of the 2023-24 federal budget strategy and outlook book in front of the media

props.synopsis: A mid-year budget update reveals higher interest rates are also hurting the Commonwealth's bottom line, as loan repayments overtake the NDIS to become the government's fastest growing spending pressure.

title.children: Loan repayments will overtake NDIS to become fastest growing spending pressure on federal budget

image.altText: Ariarne smiles softly in a selfie of her lying in bed in her silk stripped pajamas.

props.synopsis: When Olympic swimmer Ariarne Titmus had to have surgery in September she was reluctant to go public but selfie requests from nurses led to her changing tack and now she wants to normalise conversations about women's health.Â

title.children: Ariarne Titmus intended to keep her surgery 'under wraps' but selfie requests from nurses changed that

image.altText: a close up photo of a hand drawing a picture of a handfish with a blue pencil

props.synopsis: Tasmanian artist Lucienne Rickard could have made about $100,000 from selling her detailed drawings of animals. Instead, she hopes erasing her work will enhance the creatures' chance of survival.

title.children: Just like these drawings, the animals depicted face erasure

image.altText: Perth Scorchers batter Josh Inglis speaks to Melbourne Renegades' Joe Clarke as they walk off the field at a Big Bash game.

props.synopsis: Hours of heavy rain in the Geelong area seem to have affected the pitch at Kardinia Park, prompting the BBL clash between the Melbourne Renegades and Perth Scorchers to be called off.

title.children: 'The wicket's absolutely drenched': Big Bash game called off due to unplayable pitch in Geelong

image.altText: Culturally significant artefacts by William Barak at an exhibition

props.synopsis: Two works by Aboriginal artist and advocate William Barak will go on display this week after being returned to Victoria 120 years after they were gifted to a Swiss family.

title.children: Aboriginal artist William Barak's work to go on display this week after historic return

image.altText: A hand touches the place of a disappeared metal plaque which was a tribute to a victim of Joseph Stalin.

props.synopsis: Plaques placed around Moscow to pay tribute to the victims of the Soviet leader are disappearing from the city's streets.

title.children: 'Bygone era': The disappearing plaques for Stalin victims from Moscow's streets

image.altText: Campbell Newman and Annastacia Palaszczuk

props.synopsis: Annastacia Palaszczuk leaves politics having blazed a path for women in Australia and will be celebrated as a Labor legend who brought the party back from humiliation and defeat.

title.children: Annastacia Palaszczuk, the 'accidental premier' who became a Labor legend and trailblazer for women

image.altText: Huge amount of smoke behind homes.

props.synopsis: A bushfire forces residents to evacuate and closes a major highway as extreme fire weather hits.

title.children: Residents forced to evacuate as 'out of control' fire threatens homes in WA's Mid-West

image.altText: A portrait of a young girl outdoors, smiling into the camera. The background is of bushland, grass and woodchips on the ground.

props.synopsis: Watching water go to waste while waiting for the shower to get hot sparked an idea that high school student Rani East-Jeffs hopes can help save thousands of litres of the precious resource. It's also caught the attention of Australia's inventors.

title.children: Do you use a bucket in the shower to save water? This award-winning young inventor has found a better solution

image.altText: Orange flames and thick black smoke billow from a burning factory.

props.synopsis: A body has been recovered by police following a large factory fire that burnt for about nine hours on Friday.

title.children: Body recovered after factory fire in Melbourne's south east

image.altText: Police speak to a group of people standing near an escalator.

props.synopsis: Sydney's inner-west community waited four years for the escalators at Ashfield Shopping Centre to be repaired and reopened, but their appreciation party nearly plummeted when security staff called police.

title.children: Mall security 'jump the gun' and call NSW police after locals gather to celebrate escalator reopening

image.altText: a silhouette of a woman with her hands in the air at a music festival

props.synopsis: Four attendees of the Epik music festival at Sydney Olympic Park have been rushed to hospital due to drug-related issues, according to NSW Health Minister Ryan Park.

title.children: Four revellers hospitalised from 'drug issues' after attending Sydney dance music festival

image.altText: A forensic officer in a mask, helmet and PPE looks down at a clip board in the middle of a burnt out house.

props.synopsis: Homicide detectives are investigating the stabbing death of a woman, found with critical injuries near a home believed to have been deliberately lit on fire north of Brisbane.

title.children: Man dies from burn injuries after allegedly stabbing long-term partner to death

image.altText: A sticker that reads 'SOLD' on a real estate sign outside a property.

props.synopsis: Penalties for foreign investors who leave homes vacant will face a sixfold increase, in a measure the federal government says will free up more housing stock.

title.children: Foreign investors to be slapped with huge penalties for leaving homes vacant

image.altText: A close portrait of a woman in business attire, who is looking at the camera with a neutral expression.

props.synopsis: The head of the government watchdog for the NDIS swore and said she might have to resign after she discovered she had made a mistake in telling Four Corners the regulator had shut down a program where children with disabilities were abused, court documents allege.â¯

title.children: 'I may have to resign': Court documents allege NDIS commissioner mistakenly misled Four Corners over autism program

image.altText: Prince William and Princess Kate post for a photo with their children George, Charlotte and Louis.

props.synopsis: No one does holiday cards quite like the royals with the Wales family and King and Queen sharing their chosen selections for 2023.

title.children: King Charles and Camilla, and Prince William and Kate, release new family photos for Christmas cards

image.altText: children dive into the ater at the beach, it's a sunny day and a lifeguard tower can be seen in the background

props.synopsis: You've probably heard El NiÃ±o brings hot and dry weather to the eastern states, but what about the rest of Australia? Are we all in for a scorcher this summer?

title.children: Not all states experience climate drivers equally. So, is your home in for a scorching summer?

props.synopsis: Environmentalists say whales could go deaf during seismic surveys for offshore oil and gas. The reality is more complicated.

title.children: It's one of the loudest sounds in the ocean, but is it killing whales?

image.altText: Five kids sit on the floor, dusty and bloodied with one toddler in a sling

props.synopsis: Each evening, Israelis are sitting down to watch their prime-time television news to see what's happening in the war. And each evening, the pattern is much the same, writes John Lyons.

title.children: There are two wars going on in Gaza right now â the one Israelis are watching, and the one the rest of the world sees

image.altText: Chelsea player Sam Kerr with coach Emma Hayes on the sideline of a Women's Super League match with Liverpool that was called off

props.synopsis: Outgoing Chelsea managerÂ Emma Hayes says Joey Barton's remarks are indicative of the sort of "systemic misogyny and bullying" women are repeatedly subjected to in football.

title.children: Chelsea manager calls out 'misogyny and bullying' faced by women in football after Joey Barton's rant

image.altText: A sign with no alcohol in front of a sunset

props.synopsis: The ABC this week revealed WA Police support widespread liquor restrictions across much of the state amid a doubling of alcohol-related family violence in parts of regional WA. But this information almost didn't see the light of day.Â

title.children: How a mistakenly sent email revealed shocking family violence statistics authorities didn't want you to see

image.altText: steve hero pic

props.synopsis: Residents are cleaning up after a destructive storm swept through the area, ripping roofs off buildings and knocking down trees and power poles.

title.children: Central Coast man rescued after 'freaky' storm drops neighbour's roof on his house

image.altText: A man wearing a blue robe with yellow belt around the middle, and a cap on his head, stands in front of a shed

props.synopsis: DavaadorjÂ and his family callÂ theÂ vast sand dunes of the Gobi Desert in Mongolia home and live off the land.Â But that delicate balance is shifting against them, as the terrain and the weather become even harsher and more volatile due to a rapidly changing climate.

title.children: Known as 'white death', a terrifying weather phenomenon is changing lives and unleashing horror in Mongolia
